As long as $\hat{U}(0)=\hat{U}(t_{f})=\mathbb{I}$, the state $\mbox{$\left| {\varphi(t_{f})} \right>$}$ reproduces exactly the desired target state $\mbox{$\left| {\psi(t_{f})} \right>$}$ upon completion of the STA protocol. This suggests a route to design the UE transport waveform.
The  boundary conditions $f(0)=0$ and $f(t_{f})=f_{\rm max}$ define the transport problem. Vanishing first-order derivatives $\dot{f}(0)=\dot{f}(t_{f})=0$  guarantee that $\hat{U}(0)=\hat{U}(t_{f})=\mathbb{I}$. Considering that generally we do not suddenly turn on or off control fields, we further impose  second-order boundary conditions $\ddot{f}(0)=\ddot{f}(t_{f})=0$.
These constraints are satisfied by a polynomial waveform $f(t)=10(t/t_{f})^{2}-15(t/t_{f})^{3}+6(t/t_{f})^{4}$ \cite{Torrontegui11, Deffner14}.
In the experiment, we apply the UE transport in the backward process as shown in Fig.\ \ref{Wav}.\\
\indent
For the UE transport, we measure the final average phonon number $0.026\pm0.019$ for various shortcut ratios $s$ from $1$ to $0.4$ with a step of $0.1$. As shown in Fig.\ \ref{Ins}, we also examine the process of the UE transport in the instantaneous basis (see section D of the supplementary information for the measurement in the lab frame). We observe large excitations in the process, which shows the UE protocol does not follow the adiabatic evolution, but succeeds in preparing the adiabatic target state as a final state. As shown in Fig.\ \ref{Err}, the robustness against the drift of the trap frequency is below that of the CD transport. Note that the $f(t)$ used is not the only possible solution.  Simulation results (see section E of supplementary information) show that the waveform will be more sensitive to the trap frequency error when higher order boundary conditions are considered. And the first-order polynomial waveform can also minimizes the DC Stark shift during transport with the electric fields \cite{Lau11}.\\
\indent
Finally, we implement the Fourier optimization scheme as proposed in \cite{Odelin14}. When the applied force $f(t)$ for  transport satisfies the conditions  $f(0)=0$ and $\dot{f}(0)=\dot{f}(t_{\rm f})=0$, the final excitation energy can be expressed as the Fourier transform of the acceleration of the force at the trap frequency. 

In principle, this method allows us to find a driving $f(t)$ that simultaneously minimizes the final excitation energy for an ensemble of  $N$ different trap frequencies (see the section F of the supplementary information). When their value is equalized, the final excitation is set by $(\omega'^2-\omega^2)^N$, which enhances the robustness  of the scheme against the trap frequency drift. The cost of the enhanced robustness is the increase of the amplitude of the control field with the order  $N$. In our experiment, we choose $N=3$ that   results in a oscillatory waveform, shown in Fig.\ \ref{Wav}. The required amplitude of the control field greatly surpasses $f_{\rm max}$ for a small shortcut ratio and we only test the scheme for $s=1.5$. The excitation in the instantaneous base and its robustness are shown in Fig.\ \ref{Ins} and Fig.\ \ref{Err}, respectively. \\
\indent
We have realized and compared three different STA protocols for the transport problem. In particular, we have provided the first realization of the CD protocol in a continuous variable system and demonstrated the robust adiabatic following it induces. We note that the CD  protocol is  the optimal solution of the quantum brachistochrone problem \cite{Takahashi1302} and that the amplitude of the auxiliary CD term scales as $\dot{f}(t)\hat{p}/m\omega^{2}\propto s^{-1}$. If restricted to a local potential, we may use the UE protocol, where the auxiliary term takes the simple time-dependent linear potential form $\ddot{f}(t)\hat{x}/\omega^{2}\propto s^{-2}$. This scaling indicates that for the small shortcut ratio we may need a much larger control field than for the CD protocol. We note that by further modulating the trap frequency during the transport, these shortcuts can still be accelerated within the a maximum control field with the ``rapid scan method", which has been realized for a two level system \cite{Zhang13}. For example, the total duration can be reduced to half for the tested UE protocol here (see section E of the supplementary information). As for the Fourier optimization scheme, its robustness is reduced even with respect to the UE scheme for a given amplitude of the control field, but could be increased with the order $N$ and a higher amplitude of the control field (see section F of the supplementary information). Our work is a fundamental test of STA theories, which could be applied to  engineer universal quantum gates \cite{SS15},
holonomic quantum computation \cite{Zhang14}, the scalable ion-trap quantum computer \cite{Kielpinski02} and quantum thermodynamics \cite{Deng13,delcampo14}.

The  boundary conditions $f(0)=0$ and $f(t_{f})=f_{\rm max}$ define the transport problem. Vanishing first-order derivatives $\dot{f}(0)=\dot{f}(t_{f})=0$  guarantee that $\hat{U}(0)=\hat{U}(t_{f})=\mathbb{I}$. Considering that generally we do not suddenly turn on or off control fields, we further impose  second-order boundary conditions $\ddot{f}(0)=\ddot{f}(t_{f})=0$.
These constraints are satisfied by a polynomial waveform $f(t)=10(t/t_{f})^{2}-15(t/t_{f})^{3}+6(t/t_{f})^{4}$ \cite{Torrontegui11, Deffner14}.
In the experiment, we apply the UE transport in the backward process as shown in Fig.\ \ref{Wav}.\\
\indent
For the UE transport, we measure the final average phonon number $0.026\pm0.019$ for various shortcut ratios $s$ from $1$ to $0.4$ with a step of $0.1$. As shown in Fig.\ \ref{Ins}, we also examine the process of the UE transport in the instantaneous basis (see section D of the supplementary information for the measurement in the lab frame). We observe large excitations in the process, which shows the UE protocol does not follow the adiabatic evolution, but succeeds in preparing the adiabatic target state as a final state. As shown in Fig.\ \ref{Err}, the robustness against the drift of the trap frequency is below that of the CD transport. Note that the $f(t)$ used is not the only possible solution.  Simulation results (see section E of supplementary information) show that the waveform will be more sensitive to the trap frequency error when higher order boundary conditions are considered. And the first-order polynomial waveform can also minimizes the DC Stark shift during transport with the electric fields \cite{Lau11}.\\
\indent
Finally, we implement the Fourier optimization scheme as proposed in \cite{Odelin14}. When the applied force $f(t)$ for  transport satisfies the conditions  $f(0)=0$ and $\dot{f}(0)=\dot{f}(t_{\rm f})=0$, the final excitation energy can be expressed as the Fourier transform of the acceleration of the force at the trap frequency. 

In principle, this method allows us to find a driving $f(t)$ that simultaneously minimizes the final excitation energy for an ensemble of  $N$ different trap frequencies (see the section F of the supplementary information). When their value is equalized, the final excitation is set by $(\omega'^2-\omega^2)^N$, which enhances the robustness  of the scheme against the trap frequency drift. The cost of the enhanced robustness is the increase of the amplitude of the control field with the order  $N$. In our experiment, we choose $N=3$ that   results in a oscillatory waveform, shown in Fig.\ \ref{Wav}. The required amplitude of the control field greatly surpasses $f_{\rm max}$ for a small shortcut ratio and we only test the scheme for $s=1.5$. The excitation in the instantaneous base and its robustness are shown in Fig.\ \ref{Ins} and Fig.\ \ref{Err}, respectively. \\
\indent
We have realized and compared three different STA protocols for the transport problem. In particular, we have provided the first realization of the CD protocol in a continuous variable system and demonstrated the robust adiabatic following it induces. We note that the CD  protocol is  the optimal solution of the quantum brachistochrone problem \cite{Takahashi1302} and that the amplitude of the auxiliary CD term scales as $\dot{f}(t)\hat{p}/m\omega^{2}\propto s^{-1}$. If restricted to a local potential, we may use the UE protocol, where the auxiliary term takes the simple time-dependent linear potential form $\ddot{f}(t)\hat{x}/\omega^{2}\propto s^{-2}$. This scaling indicates that for the small shortcut ratio we may need a much larger control field than for the CD protocol. We note that by further modulating the trap frequency during the transport, these shortcuts can still be accelerated within the a maximum control field with the ``rapid scan method", which has been realized for a two level system \cite{Zhang13}. For example, the total duration can be reduced to half for the tested UE protocol here (see section E of the supplementary information). As for the Fourier optimization scheme, its robustness is reduced even with respect to the UE scheme for a given amplitude of the control field, but could be increased with the order $N$ and a higher amplitude of the control field (see section F of the supplementary information). Our work is a fundamental test of STA theories, which could be applied to  engineer universal quantum gates \cite{SS15},
holonomic quantum computation \cite{Zhang14}, the scalable ion-trap quantum computer \cite{Kielpinski02} and quantum thermodynamics \cite{Deng13,delcampo14}.
